The Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO) prohibits certain conduct involving a pattern of racketeering activity
column3: and makes a private right of action available to [a]ny person injured in his business or property by reason of a violation of RICOs substantive restrictions
column5: provided that the alleged violation was the proximate cause of the injury
column6: Holmes v. Securities Investor Protection Corporation
column8: 268.  Respondent Ideal Steel Supply Corporation (Ideal) has stores in Queens and the Bronx.  Petitioner National Steel Supply
column9: Inc. (National)
column10: owned by petitioners Joseph and Vincent Anza
column11: has stores in the same locations and is Ideals principal competitor.  Ideal filed suit in the District Court
column12: claiming that National failed to charge New Yorks sales tax to cash-paying customers
column13: allowing it to reduce its prices without affecting its profit margin; and that it submitted fraudulent state tax returns to conceal the conduct
column14: which involved committing mail and wire fraud
column15: both forms of racketeering activity under RICO.  Ideal alleged that the Anzas violated 1962(c)
column16: which forbids conducting or participating in the conduct of an enterprises affairs through a pattern of racketeering activity.  It also claimed that all the petitioners violated 1962(a)which makes it unlawful for a person to use or invest income derived from a pattern of racketeering activity in an enterprise engaged in or affecting interstate or foreign commercewhen they used funds generated by the fraudulent tax scheme to open Nationals Bronx location
column17: causing Ideal to lose business and market share.  The District Court granted petitioners motion to dismiss under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6)
column18: concluding that Ideal had not shown reliance on petitioners misrepresentations
column19: as required in RICO mail and wire fraud claims.  Vacating
column22: that a complaint alleging a pattern of racketeering activity designed to give a defendant a competitive advantage adequately pleaded probable cause even where the scheme depended on fraudulent communications made to a third party; and held that Ideal adequately pleaded its 1962(a) claim by alleging injury resulting from petitioners use and investment of racketeering proceeds.

column1: Held:
1.Ideal cannot maintain its 1962(c) claim.  Under Holmes
column2: proximate cause for 1964(c) purposes requires some direct relation between the injury asserted and the injurious conduct alleged.  503 U. S.
column3: at 268.  The direct victim of the alleged RICO violation is the State of New York
column4: not Ideal.  Ideals claim is too attenuated to satisfy Holmes requirement of directness.  This result is confirmed by the directness requirements underlying premises
column5: one of which is the difficulty that can arise when a court attempts to ascertain the damages caused by some remote action.  Ideal claims lost sales because of Nationals decreased prices
column6: but National could have lowered prices for reasons unrelated to the asserted tax fraud
column7: and Ideals lost sales could have resulted from other factors as well.  The attenuated connection between Ideals injury and the Anzas injurious conduct thus implicates fundamental concerns expressed in Holmes.  Further illustrating the absence of proximate cause is the speculative nature of the proceedings that would follow if Ideal were permitted to maintain its claim.  A court would have to calculate the portion of Nationals price drop attributable to the pattern of racketeering activity and then calculate the portion of lost sales attributable to the relevant part of the price drop
column8: but Holmes proximate causation element was meant to prevent such intricate
column9: uncertain inquiries from overrunning RICO litigation.  A direct causal connection is especially warranted where the immediate victims can be expected to vindicate the laws by pursuing their own claims.  Contrary to the Second Circuits rationale
column10: a RICO plaintiff cannot circumvent the proximate-cause requirement simply by claiming that the defendants aim was to increase market share at a competitors expense.  Because Ideal has not satisfied that requirement
column11: this Court has no occasion to address the substantial question whether a plaintiff asserting a RICO claim predicated on mail or wire fraud must show that it relied on the defendants misrepresentations.  Pp.49.

column1: 2.The Second Circuits judgment with respect to Ideals 1962(a) claim is vacated so that court can determine on remand whether petitioners alleged 1962(a) violation proximately caused Ideals asserted injuries.  Pp.910.

column1: 05-130|"EBAY INC. etal. v. MERCEXCHANGE
certiorari to the united states court of appeals for the federal circuit
No. 05130.Argued March 29
Petitioners operate popular Internet Web sites that allow private sellers to list goods they wish to sell.  Respondent sought to license its business method patent to petitioners
column2: but no agreement was reached.  In respondents subsequent patent infringement suit
column3: a jury found that its patent was valid
column4: that petitioners had infringed the patent
column5: and that damages were appropriate.  However
column6: the District Court denied respondents motion for permanent injunctive relief.  In reversing
column7: the Federal Circuit applied its general rule that courts will issue permanent injunctions against patent infringement absent exceptional circumstances.  401 F.3d 1323

column1: Held:The traditional four-factor test applied by courts of equity when considering whether to award permanent injunctive relief to a prevailing plaintiff applies to disputes arising under the Patent Act.  That test requires a plaintiff to demonstrate: (1) that it has suffered an irreparable injury; (2) that remedies available at law are inadequate to compensate for that injury; (3) that considering the balance of hardships between the plaintiff and defendant
column2: a remedy in equity is warranted; and (4) that the public interest would not be disserved by a permanent injunction.  The decision to grant or deny such relief is an act of equitable discretion by the district court
column3: reviewable on appeal for abuse of discretion.  These principles apply with equal force to Patent Act disputes.  [A] major departure from the long tradition of equity practice should not be lightly implied.  Weinberger v. Romero&nbhyph;Barcelo
column5: 320.  Nothing in the Act indicates such a departure.  Pp.26.

SERVICES

No. 05260.Argued March 28

Petitioner Sereboffs are beneficiaries under a health insurance plan administered by respondent Mid Atlantic and covered by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA).  The plan provides for payment of covered medical expenses and has an Acts of Third Parties provision.  This provision requires a beneficiary who is injured as a result of an act or omission of a third party to reimburse Mid Atlantic for benefits it pays on account of those injuries
column2: if the beneficiary recovers for those injuries from the third party.  The Sereboffs were involved in an automobile accident and suffered injuries.  The plan paid the couples medical expenses.  The Sereboffs sought compensatory damages for the accident from third parties in state court.  After the Sereboffs settled their tort suit
column3: Mid Atlantic filed suit in District Court under 502(a)(3) of ERISA
column4: seeking to collect from the Sereboffs tort recovery the medical expenses it had paid on the Sereboffs behalf.  The Sereboffs agreed to set aside from their tort recovery a sum equal to the amount Mid Atlantic claimed
column5: and preserve this sum in an investment account pending the outcome of the suit.  The court found in Mid Atlantics favor and ordered the Sereboffs to turn over the amount set aside.  The Fourth Circuit affirmed in relevant part
column6: and observed that the Courts of Appeals are divided on the question whether 502(a)(3) authorizes recovery in these circumstances.  This Court granted review to resolve this disagreement.

column3: this Court construed 502(a)(3)(B) to authorize only those categories of relief that were typically available in equity
column4: and thus rejected a claim that this Court found sought nothing other than compensatory damages.  Id.

column7: which involved a provision in an ERISA plan similar to the Acts of Third Parties provision in the Sereboffs plan.  Relying on such a provision
column8: Great-West sought equitable restitution of benefits it had paid when Knudson recovered in tort from a third party.  In considering whether 502(a)(3)(b) authorized such relief
column9: this Court asked whether the restitutionary remedy Great-West sought would have been equitable in the days of the divided bench
column10: id.
column11: at 212.  This Court found that it would not have been equitable
column12: because the funds Great-West sought were not in Knudsons possession but had been placed in a trust under California law.  That impediment is not present here.  Mid Atlantic sought identifiable funds within the Sereboffs possession and controlthat part of the tort settlement due Mid Atlantic under the ERISA plan and set aside in the investment account. column10: which the other attorneys could follow  into [Barnes] hands as soon as [the fund] was identified

column16: Mid Atlantic could rely on a familiar rul[e] of equity to collect for the medical bills it had paid by following a portion of the recovery into the [Sereboffs] hands as soon as [the settlement fund] was identified
column17: and imposing on that portion a constructive trust or equitable lien.  Ibid.

column1: 04-1327|"HOLMES v. SOUTH CAROLINA
certiorari to the supreme court of south carolina
No. 041327.Argued February 22
At petitioners South Carolina trial for murder and related crimes
column2: the prosecution relied heavily on forensic evidence that strongly supported petitioners guilt.  Petitioner sought to undermine the States forensic evidence by introducing expert testimony suggesting that the evidence had been contaminated and that the police had engaged in a plot to frame him.  Petitioner also sought to introduce evidence that another man
column3: Jimmy McCaw White
column4: had been in the victims neighborhood on the morning of the assault and that White had either acknowledged petitioners innocence or admitted to committing the crimes himself.  In Whites pretrial testimony
column5: he denied making the incriminating statements and provided an alibi for the time of the assault.

column1: The trial court excluded petitioners third-party guilt evidence citing the State Supreme Courts Gregory decision
column2: which held such evidence admissible if it raises a reasonable inference as to the defendants own innocence
column3: but inadmissible if it merely casts a bare suspicion or raises a conjectural inference as to anothers guilt.  Affirming the trial court
column4: the State Supreme Court cited both Gregory and its later decision in Gay
column5: and held that where there is strong forensic evidence of an appellants guilt
column6: proffered evidence about a third partys alleged guilt does not raise a reasonable inference as to the appellants own innocence.  Applying this standard
column7: the court held that petitioner could not overcome the forensic evidence against him.

column1: Held:A criminal defendants federal constitutional rights are violated by an evidence rule under which the defendant may not introduce evidence of third-party guilt if the prosecution has introduced forensic evidence that
column3: strongly supports a guilty verdict.  [S]tate and federal rulemakers have broad latitude under the Constitution to establish rules excluding evidence from criminal trials.  United States v. Scheffer
column5: 308.  This latitude
column7: has limits.  Whether rooted directly in the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment or in the Compulsory Process or Confrontation clauses of the Sixth Amendment
column8: the Constitution guarantees criminal defendants a meaningful opportunity to present a complete defense.  Crane v. Kentucky
column10: 690.  This right is abridged by evidence rules that infring[e] upon a weighty interest of the accused and are arbitrary or disproportionate to the purposes they are designed to serve.  Scheffer

column1: While the Constitution thus prohibits the exclusion of defense evidence under rules that serve no legitimate purpose or that are disproportionate to the ends that they are asserted to promote
column2: well-established rules of evidence permit trial judges to exclude evidence if its probative value is outweighed by certain other factors such as unfair prejudice
column3: confusion of the issues
column4: or potential to mislead the jury.  An application of this principle is found in rules regulating the admission of evidence proffered by criminal defendants to show that someone else committed the crime with which they are charged.  Such rules are widely accepted and are not challenged here.

column1: In Gregory
column2: the South Carolina Supreme Court adopted and applied a rule intended to be of this type.  In Gay and this case
column3: however
column4: that court radically changed and extended the Gregory rule by holding that
column5: where there is strong evidence of a defendants guilt
column7: proffered evidence about a third partys alleged guilt may (or perhaps must) be excluded.  Under this rule
column8: the trial judge does not focus on the probative value or the potential adverse effects of admitting the defense evidence of third-party guilt.  Instead
column9: the critical inquiry concerns the strength of the prosecutions case: If the prosecutions case is strong enough
column10: the evidence of third-party guilt is excluded even if that evidence
column12: would have great probative value and even if it would not pose an undue risk of harassment
column14: or confusion of the issues.  Furthermore
column16: the rule seems to call for little
column17: if any
column18: examination of the credibility of the prosecutions witnesses or the reliability of its evidence.

column1: By evaluating the strength of only one partys evidence
column2: no logical conclusion can be reached regarding the strength of contrary evidence offered by the other side to rebut or cast doubt.  Because the rule applied below did not heed this point
column3: the rule is arbitrary in the sense that it does not rationally serve the end that the Gregory rule and other similar third-party guilt rules were designed to further.  Nor has the State identified any other legitimate end served by the rule.  Thus
column4: the rule violates a criminal defendants right to have a meaningful opportunity to present a complete defense.  Crane
column5: supra

column3: vacated and remanded.

certiorari to the supreme court of arkansas

Petitioner Jones continued to pay the mortgage on his Arkansas home after separating from his wife and moving elsewhere in the same city.  Once the mortgage was paid off
column2: the property taxeswhich had been paid by the mortgage companywent unpaid
column3: and the property was certified as delinquent.  Respondent Commissioner of State Lands mailed Jones a certified letter at the propertys address
column4: stating that unless he redeemed the property
column5: it would be subject to public sale in two years.  Nobody was home to sign for the letter and nobody retrieved it from the post office within 15 days
column6: so it was returned to the Commissioner
column7: marked unclaimed.  Two years later
column8: the Commissioner published a notice of public sale in a local newspaper.  No bids were submitted
column9: so the State negotiated a private sale to respondent Flowers.  Before selling the house
column10: the Commissioner mailed another certified letter to Jones
column11: which was also returned unclaimed.  Flowers purchased the house and had an unlawful detainer notice delivered to the property.  It was served on Jones daughter
column12: who notified him of the sale.  He filed a state-court suit against respondents
column13: alleging that the Commissioners failure to provide adequate notice resulted in the taking of his property without due process.  Granting respondents summary judgment
column14: the trial court concluded that Arkansas tax sale statute
column15: which sets out the notice procedure used here
column16: complied with due process.  The State Supreme Court affirmed.

column1: Held:
1.When mailed notice of a tax sale is returned unclaimed
column2: a State must take additional reasonable steps to attempt to provide notice to the property owner before selling his property
column3: if it is practicable to do so.  Pp.412.

column1: (a)This Court has deemed notice constitutionally sufficient if it was reasonably calculated to reach the intended recipient when sent
column3: e.g.
column4: Mullane v. Central Hanover Bank & Trust Co.
column7: but has never addressed whether due process requires further efforts when the government becomes aware prior to the taking that its notice attempt has failed.  Most Courts of Appeals and State Supreme Courts addressing this question have decided that the government must do more in such a case
column8: and many state statutes require more than mailed notice in the first instance.  Pp.46.

column1: (b)The means a State employs to provide notice must be such as one desirous of actually informing the absentee might reasonably adopt to accomplish it.  Mullane
column3: at 315.  The adequacy of a particular form of notice is assessed by balancing the States interest against the individual interest sought to be protected by the Fourteenth Amendment.  Id.

It is unlikely that a person who actually desired to inform an owner about an impending tax sale of a house would do nothing when a certified letter addressed to the owner is returned unclaimed.  The sender would ordinarily attempt to resend the letter
column7: especially given that it concerns the important and irreversible prospect of losing a house.  The State may have made a reasonable calculation of how to reach Jones
column8: but it had good reason to suspect when the notice was returned that Jones was no better off than if no notice had been sent. Hanrahan

column11: and Covey v. Town of Somers

column19: the ex ante principle is not contravened by considering what the government does with that information.  None of the Commissioners additional contentionsthat notice was sent to an address that Jones provided and had a legal obligation to keep updated

column21: and that Jones was obliged to ensure that those in whose hands he left his property would alert him if it was in jeopardyrelieves the State of its constitutional obligation to provide adequate notice.  Pp.712.

column3: the Commissioners effort to provide notice to Jones was insufficient to satisfy due process.  What is reasonable in response to new information depends on what that information reveals.  The certified letters return unclaimed meant either that Jones was not home when the postman called and did not retrieve the letter or that he no longer resided there.  One reasonable step addressed to the former possibility would be for the State to resend the notice by regular mail
column4: which requires no signature.  Certified mail makes actual notice more likely only if someone is there to sign for the letter or tell the mail carrier that the address is incorrect.  Regular mail can be left until the person returns home
column5: and might increase the chances of actual notice.  Other reasonable follow-up measures would have been to post notice on the front door or address otherwise undeliverable mail to occupant.  Either approach would increase the likelihood that any occupants would alert the owner

column1: Held:A plaintiff in a retaliatory-prosecution action must plead and show the absence of probable cause for pressing the underlying criminal charges.  Pp.515.

column4: for speaking out.  Crawford-El v. Britton

column2: the need to demonstrate causation in the retaliatory-prosecution context presents an additional difficulty which can be overcome by a showing of the absence of probable cause.  In an ordinary retaliation case
column3: the evidence of motive and injury are sufficient for a circumstantial demonstration that the one caused the other

Demonstrating a lack of probable cause will tend to reinforce the retaliation evidence and show that retaliation was the but-for basis for instigating the prosecution
column10: while establishing the existence of probable cause will suggest that the prosecution would have occurred even without a retaliatory motive.  Second
column11: since the defendant in a retaliatory-prosecution case will not be the prosecutor
column13: but an official who allegedly influenced the prosecutorial decision
column14: the causal connection required is not between the retaliatory animus of one person and that persons own injurious action

column16: but between the retaliatory animus of one person and the adverse action of another.  Because evidence of an inspectors animus does not necessarily show that the inspector induced the prosecutor to act when he would not have pressed charges otherwise and because of the longstanding presumption of regularity accorded prosecutorial decisionmaking
column17: a showing of the absence of probable cause is needed to bridge the gap between the nonprosecuting government agents retaliatory motive and the prosecutors injurious action and to rebut the presumption.  Pp.613.

column1: (c)The significance of probable cause or the lack of it looms large
column2: being a potential feature of every case
column3: with obvious evidentiary value.   Though not necessarily dispositive
column4: the absence of probable cause along with a retaliatory motive on the part of the official urging prosecution are reasonable grounds to suspend the presumption of regularity behind the charging decision and enough for a prima facie inference that the unconstitutionally motivated inducement infected the prosecutors decision to go forward.  Pp.1315.

certiorari to the united states court of appeals for the eleventh circuit

The Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 (AEDPA) sets a one-year limitation period for filing a state prisoners federal habeas corpus petition
column2: running from the date on which the judgment became final by the conclusion of direct review or the expiration of the time for seeking such review
column4: but stops the one-year clock while the petitioners properly filed application for state postconviction relief is pending
column5: 2244(d)(2).  Under Eleventh Circuit precedent
column7: that tolling period does not include the 90 days in which a petitioner might have sought certiorari review in this Court challenging state-court denial of postconviction relief.

column1: Petitioner Days Florida trial-court sentence was affirmed on December 21
column3: and his time to seek this Courts review of the final state-court decision expired on March 20
column4: 2000.  Day unsuccessfully sought state postconviction relief 353 days later.  The trial courts judgment was affirmed on appeal
column5: effective December 3
column6: 2002.  Day petitioned for federal habeas relief 36 days later
column7: on January 8
column8: 2003.  Floridas answer asserted that the petition was timely because it was filed after 352 days of untolled time.  Inspecting the answer and attachments
column9: however
column10: a Federal Magistrate Judge determined that the State had miscalculated the tolling time: Under the controlling Eleventh Circuit precedent
column11: the untolled time was actually 388 days
column12: rendering the petition untimely.  After affording Day an opportunity to show cause why the petition should not be dismissed for failure to meet AEDPAs one-year deadline
column13: the Magistrate Judge found petitioners responses inadequate and recommended dismissal.  The District Court adopted the recommendation
column15: concluding that a States patently erroneous concession of timeliness does not compromise a district courts authority sU. S.onte to dismiss a habeas petition as untimely.

column1: Held:In the circumstances here presented
column2: the District Court had discretion to correct the States erroneous computation and
column3: accordingly
column4: to dismiss the habeas petition as untimely under AEDPAs one-year limitation.  Pp.211.

column1: (a)A statute of limitations defense is not jurisdictional
column2: therefore courts are under no obligation to raise the matter sU. S.onte.  Cf. Kontrick v. Ryan
column5: a defendant forfeits a statute of limitations defense not asserted in its answer or in an amendment thereto.  See Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 8(c)
column7: and 15(a) (made applicable to federal habeas proceedings by Rule 11 of the Rules governing such proceedings).  And the Court would count it an abuse of discretion to override a States deliberate waiver of the limitations defense.  But
column8: in appropriate circumstances
column9: a district court may raise a time bar on its own initiative.  The District Court in this case confronted no intelligent waiver on the States part
column10: only an evident miscalculation of time.  In this situation the Court declines to adopt either an inflexible rule requiring dismissal whenever AEDPAs one-year clock has run
column13: a rule treating the States failure initially to plead the one-year bar as an absolute waiver.  Rather
column14: the Court holds that a district court has discretion to decide whether the administration of justice is better served by dismissing the case on statute of limitations grounds or by reaching the merits of the petition.  This resolution aligns the statute of limitations with other affirmative defenses to habeas petitions
column17: and nonretroactivity.  In Granberry v. Greer
column20: this Court held that federal appellate courts have discretion to consider a state prisoners failure to exhaust available state remedies before invoking federal habeas jurisdiction despite the States failure to interpose the exhaustion defense at the district-court level.  Similarly
column24: the Court held that a federal court may
column25: but need not
column26: decline to apply [the nonretroactivity rule announced in Teague v. Lane
column29: ] if the State does not argue it.  It would make scant sense to distinguish AEDPAs time bar from these other threshold constraints on federal habeas petitioners.  While a district court is not required to double-check the States math
column30: cf. Pliler v. Ford
column33: no Rule
column34: statute
column35: or constitutional provision commands a judge who detects a clear computation error to suppress that knowledge.  Cf. Fed. Rule Civ. Proc. 60(a).  The Court notes particularly that the Magistrate Judge
column37: might have informed the State of its obvious computation error and entertained an amendment to the States answer.  See
column38: e.g.
column39: Fed. Rule Civ. Proc. 15(a).  There is no dispositive difference between that route
column40: and the one taken here.  Pp.210.

column1: (b)Before acting sU. S.onte
column2: a court must accord the parties fair notice and an opportunity to present their positions.  It must also assure itself that the petitioner is not significantly prejudiced by the delayed focus on the limitation issue
column3: and determine whether the interests of justice would be better served by addressing the merits or by dismissing the petition as time barred.  See Granberry
column5: at 136. Here
column6: the Magistrate Judge gave Day due notice and a fair opportunity to show why the limitation period should not yield dismissal.  The notice issued some nine months after the States answer.  No court proceedings or action occurred in the interim
column7: and nothing suggests that the State strategically withheld the defense or chose to relinquish it.  From all that appears in the record
column8: there was merely an inadvertent error
column9: a miscalculation that was plain under Circuit precedent
column10: and no abuse of discretion in following Granberry and Caspari.  P.11.

column1: 04-1618|"NORTHERN INSURANCE COMPANY OF NEW YORK v. CHATHAM COUNTY

column2: the District Court recognized that Eleventh Amendment immunity from suit does not extend to counties

column5: exercise power delegated from the State.  The Eleventh Circuit
column6: which was bound by that same precedent

column9: under other Circuit precedent

A Magistrate Judge issued an anticipatory search warrant for respondent Grubbs house based on a federal officers affidavit.  The affidavit explained that the warrant would not be executed until a parcel containing a videotape of child pornographywhich Grubbs had ordered from an undercover postal inspectorwas received at
column3: the residence.  The affidavit also referred to two attachments describing the residence and the items to be seized.  After the package was delivered and the search commenced
column4: Grubbs was given a copy of the warrant
column5: which included the attachments but not the supporting affidavit.  When he admitted ordering the videotape
column7: and the videotape and other items were seized.  Following his indictment for receiving child pornography
column9: Grubbs moved to suppress the seized evidence
column10: arguing
column12: that the warrant was invalid because it failed to list the triggering condition.  The District Court denied the motion
column13: and Grubbs pleaded guilty.  The Ninth Circuit reversed
column14: concluding that the warrant ran afoul of the Fourth Amendments particularity requirement
column17: applied to the conditions precedent to an anticipatory warrant.

column1: Held:
1.Anticipatory warrants are not categorically unconstitutional under the Fourth Amendments provision that no Warrants shall issue
column2: but upon probable cause.  Probable cause exists when there is a fair probability that contraband or evidence of a crime will be found in a particular place.  Illinois v. Gates
column4: 238.  When an anticipatory warrant is issued
column5: the fact that the contraband is not presently at the place described is immaterial
column6: so long as there is probable cause to believe it will be there when the warrant is executed.  Anticipatory warrants are
column7: therefore
column8: no different in principle from ordinary warrants: They require the magistrate to determine (1) that it is now probable that (2) contraband
column9: evidence of a crime
column10: or a fugitive will be on the described premises (3) when the warrant is executed.  Where the anticipatory warrant places a condition (other than the mere passage of time) upon its execution
column11: the first of these determinations goes not merely to what will probably be found if the condition is met
column12: but also to the likelihood that the condition will be met
column13: and thus that a proper object of seizure will be on the described premises.  Here
column14: the occurrence of the triggering conditionsuccessful delivery of the videotapewould plainly establish probable cause for the search
column15: and the affidavit established probable cause to believe the triggering condition would be satisfied.  Pp.37.

column1: 2.The warrant at issue did not violate the Fourth Amendments particularity requirement.  The Amendment specifies only two matters that the warrant must particularly describ[e]: the place to be searched and the persons or things to be seized.  That language is decisive here; the particularity requirement does not include the conditions precedent to execution of the warrant.  Cf. Dalia v. United States
column4: 257.  Respondents two policy rationalesthat setting forth the triggering condition in the warrant itself is necessary (1) to delineate the limits of the executing officers power and (2) to allow the individual whose property is searched or seized to police the officers conductfind no basis in either the Fourth Amendment or Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 41.  Pp.79.

column15: the State Supreme Courts decision quite clearly rested  solely on the Federal Constitution.  California v. Ramos

column2: 28 U. S.C. 1602 et seq. (2000 ed. and Supp. III)
column3: forbids that attachment.

column1: The judgment for money damages consists of a default judgment against the Islamic Republic of Iran (for about $300 million) that the private citizen
column3: obtained in a federal-court lawsuit claiming that the Republic had murdered his brother.  Elahi v. Islamic Republic of Iran
column5: 103 (DC 2000).  The asset is an arbitration award (against a third party)
column6: which Irans Ministry of Defense obtained in Switzerland.  Ministry of Defense and Support for Armed Forces of Islamic Republic of Iran v. Cubic Defense Systems
column7: Inc.
column9: 1211 (CA9 2004).  The Ministry asked the Federal District Court for the Southern District of California to confirm the award.  Ministry of Defense and Support for Armed Forces of Islamic Republic of Iran v. Cubic Defense Systems
column10: Inc.
column11: 236 F.Supp. 2d 1140 (2002).  The court did so.  And Elahi then intervened
column12: seeking to impose a lien upon the award.  The Ministry opposed the attachment on the ground that the Act grants it immunity from such a claim.

column1: The Federal District Court rejected the Ministrys immunity defense on the ground that
column2: by suing to enforce the award
column3: the Ministry had waived any such immunity.  On appeal the Ninth Circuit disagreed with the District Court about waiver.  But it then found against the Ministry on a different grounda ground that the parties had not argued.  The Act says that under certain conditions the property of an agency or instrumentality of a foreign government is not  immune from attachment if the agency is engaged in commercial activity in the United States.  28 U. S.C. 1610(b) (emphasis added).  The Court of Appeals found that the Ministry engages in commercial activity and that the other conditions were satisfied.  385 F.3d
column4: at 12191222 (applying 1610(b)(2)).  And it held that this section of the Act barred the Ministrys assertion of immunity.  Ibid.

column1: The Ministry filed a petition for certiorari asking us to review that decision.  The Solicitor General agrees with the Ministry that we should grant the writ but limited to the Ministrys Question 1
column2: namely whether the property of a foreign state stricto sensu
column3: situated in the United States is immune from attachment  as provided in the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act.  Pet. for Cert. i (citing 1603(a)
column4: 1610(a)). Brief for United States as Amicus Curiae 1517.  We grant the writ limited to Question 1.

column1: The Act
column2: as it applies to the property in the United States of a foreign state
column3: 1610(a) (emphasis added)
column4: does not contain the engaged in commercial activity exception that the Ninth Circuit described. That exception applies only where the property at issue is property of an agency or instrumentality of a foreign state.  Compare 1610(b) (property  of an agency or instrumentality of a foreign state engaged in commercial activity) with 1610(a) (property  of a foreign state used for a commercial activity) (emphasis added).  The difference is critical.  Moreover
column5: in the Solicitor Generals view a defense ministry (unlike
column7: a government-owned commercial enterprise) generally is not an agency or instrumentality of a foreign state but an inseparable part of the state itself.  Brief for United States as Amicus Curiae 811; see also Transaero
column8: Inc. v. La Fuerza Aerea Boliviana
column10: 153 (CADC 1994) (hold[ing] that armed forces are as a rule so closely bound up with the structure of the state that they must in all cases be considered as the foreign state itself
column11: rather than a separate agency or instrumentality of the state).

column1: We shall not now determine whether the Solicitor General is correct about the status of the Ministry
column2: for the Ninth Circuit did not address the question nor did the parties argue the matter before the Circuit.  Neither can we fault the Ministry for that failure.  As we said
column3: supra
column5: the District Court based its denial of immunity upon waiver.  The parties Ninth Circuit briefs focused on matters not relevant here (such as the waiver question)
column6: with one exception.  The exception consists of a footnote in Elahis brief mentioning the Acts agency and instrumentality provision.  That footnote
column7: however
column8: does not ask for affirmance on that basis; nor did it provide the Ministry with clear notice that a reply was necessary.  Answering Brief of Appellee in No. 0355015 (CA9)
column10: n. 27 (stating that [i]f [the Ministry] is considered an agency or instrumentality of a foreign state
column11: rather than the foreign state itself
column12: Mr. Elahis attachment still is valid (emphasis added)).

column1: The Ninth Circuit said that it was free to affirm on any ground supported by the record.  385 F.3d
column3: n. 15.  But the court did not explain what in the record might demonstrate that the Ministry is an agency or instrumentality of the state rather than an integral part of the state itself.  The court noted that Elahi appears to concede that the Ministry is an agency and instrumentality
column7: but any relevant concession would have to have come from the Ministry
column8: not from Elahi
column9: whose position the concession favors.  Thus
column10: in implicitly concluding that the Ministry was an agency or instrumentality of the Republic of Iran within the meaning of 1610(b)
column11: the Ninth Circuit either mistakenly relied on a concession by respondent that could not possibly bind petitioner
column12: or else erroneously presumed that there was no relevant distinction between a foreign state and its agencies or instrumentalities for purposes of that subsection.  See 1603(a)
column14: the Ninth Circuit committed error that was essential to its judgment in favor of respondent.

column1: Because the Ninth Circuit did not consider
column2: and the Ministry had no reasonable opportunity to argue
column3: the critical legal point we have mentioned
column4: we vacate the judgment of the Ninth Circuit
column5: and remand the case for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

column1: A trial proceeded in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama.  At the close of the plaintiffs evidence

column1: The judgment of the Court of Appeals

column5: the Court of Appeals erred in two respects

column1: First

column4: had referred on some occasions to each of the petitioners as boy.  Petitioners argued this was evidence of discriminatory animus.  The Court of Appeals disagreed

column14: and historical usage.  Insofar as the Court of Appeals held that modifiers or qualifications are necessary in all instances to render the disputed term probative of bias

Petitioners had introduced evidence that their qualifications were superior to those of the two successful applicants.  (Part of the employers defense was that the plant with the openings had performance problems and petitioners already worked there in a supervisory capacity.)  The Court of Appeals
column3: in finding petitioners evidence insufficient

column4: to show pretext.  See Patterson v. McLean Credit Union

column9: 259 (1981) (The fact that a court may think that the employer misjudged the qualifications of the applicants does not in itself expose him to Title VII liability

column14: combined with sufficient evidence to find that the employers asserted justification is false

column1: The visual image of words jumping off the page to slap you (presumably a court) in the face is unhelpful and imprecise as an elaboration of the standard for inferring pretext from superior qualifications.  Federal courts

column5: e.g.
column7: supra

column1: 05-555|"KEITH LANCE
column3: APPELLANTS v. GIGI DENNIS

column1: COLORADO SECRETARY OF STATE
on appeal from the united states district court for the district of colorado
No. 05555.Decided February 21
Per Curiam.

The Rooker-Feldman doctrine prevents the lower federal courts from exercising jurisdiction over cases brought by state-court losers challenging state-court judgments rendered before the district court proceedings commenced.  Exxon Mobil Corp. v. Saudi Basic Industries Corp.
column3: 284 (2005).  In this case
column4: the District Court dismissed plaintiffs suit on the ground that they were in privity with a state-court loser.  We hold that the Rooker-Feldman doctrine does not bar plaintiffs from proceeding
column5: and vacate the District Courts judgment.

column1: I
This is the latest of several rounds of litigation involving the State of Colorados congressional redistricting after the 2000 census
column2: under which the State gained a seat in the House of Representatives.  Lance v. Davidson
column4: 1121 (2005).  The first round began in May 2001.  When the Colorado General Assembly failed to pass a redistricting plan for the 2002 congressional elections by the close of its regular session
column5: a group of Colorado voters asked the state courts to create a plan.  The courts agreed
column6: drawing a new map reflecting the additional district.  See Beauprez v.  Avalos
column7: 42 P.3d 642 (Colo. 2002) (en banc).  The 2002 elections were held using this court-ordered plan.

column1: The General Assembly passed its own redistricting plan in the spring of 2003
column2: prompting further litigationthis time about which electoral map was to govern
column3: the legislatures or the courts.  Two suits were filed seeking to enjoin the legislatures plan: an original action in the Colorado Supreme Court by the state attorney general seeking to require the secretary of state to use the court-ordered plan
column4: and a similar action brought in a lower state court by several proponents of the court-ordered plan.  379 F.Supp. 2d
column5: at 1121.  After the Colorado General Assembly intervened to defend its plan in the first case
column6: the Colorado Supreme Court held that the plan violated Article V
column8: of the State Constitution
column9: which the court construed to limit congressional redistricting to once per decade.  People ex rel. Salazar v. Davidson
column11: 1231 (2003) (en banc).  It therefore ordered the secretary of state to use the court-created plan.  We denied certiorari.  541 U. S. 1093 (2004).

column1: The second suit was removed to federal court by the defendants on the basis of plaintiffs federal-law claims.  See Keller v. Davidson
column3: 1175 (Colo. 2004).  Once Salazar was decided by the Colorado Supreme Court
column4: the viability of the defendants counterclaims was the only remaining issue.  A three-judge District Court held that the defendants were barred by the Rooker-Feldman doctrine from amending their counterclaims to assert additional challenges to the decision in Salazar.  It also held that the defendants original counterclaims
column5: while not barred by the Rooker-Feldman doctrine
column6: were precluded under Colorado law by the judgment in Salazar.  Accordingly
column7: the court dismissed the case.

column1: Finally
column2: this suit: Before the dismissal in Keller
column3: several Colorado citizens unhappy with Salazar filed an action in the District Court seeking to require the secretary of state to use the legislatures plan.[Footnote 1]  The plaintiffs argued that Article V
column5: of the Colorado Constitution
column6: as interpreted by the Colorado Supreme Court
column7: violated the Elections Clause of Article I
column9: of the U. S. Constitution (The Times
column10: Places and Manner of holding Elections for Senators and Representatives
column11: shall be prescribed in each State by the Legislature thereof)
column12: and the First Amendments Petition Clause (Congress shall make no law  abridging  the right of the people  to petition the Government for a redress of grievances).  The defendants filed a motion to dismiss
column13: arguing that the Rooker-Feldman doctrine and Colorado preclusion law barred any attack on the Colorado Supreme Courts judgment in Salazar and that the plaintiffs had failed to state a valid Petition Clause claim.

column1: The three-judge District Court ruled that under the Rooker-Feldman doctrine
column2: it had no jurisdiction to hear the Elections Clause claim.  379 F.Supp. 2d
column3: at 1127.  The Rooker-Feldman doctrine
column5: includes three requirements: (1) the party against whom the doctrine is invoked must have actually been a party to the prior state-court judgment or have been in privity with such a party; (2) the claim raised in the federal suit must have been actually raised or inextricably intertwined with the state-court judgment; and (3) the federal claim must not be parallel to the state-court claim.  379 F.Supp. 2d
column6: at 1124.  The District Court found the first requirement satisfied on the ground that the citizen plaintiffs were in privity with the Colorado General Assemblya losing party in Salazar.  Relying on our decisions in Washington v. Washington State Commercial Passenger Fishing Vessel Assn.
column8: and Tacoma v. Taxpayers of Tacoma
column10: the court stated that when a state government litigates a matter of public concern
column11: that states citizens will be deemed to be in privity with the government for preclusion purposes.  379 F.Supp. 2d
column14: applies with equal force in the Rooker-Feldman context.  Ibid.  The court went on to conclude that the Elections Clause claim was actually raised in Salazar
column15: or inextricably intertwined with that decision
column16: and was not parallel to the claims presented in Salazar.  As to the Petition Clause claim
column17: the court ruled that neither Rooker-Feldman nor Colorado preclusion law prevented the court from proceeding to the merits
column18: but that plaintiffs failed to state a claim.  379 F.Supp. 2d
column19: at 1132; see Fed. Rule Civ. Proc.12(b)(6).

column1: The plaintiffs appealed.  See 28 U. S.C. 1253.  We now note jurisdiction
column2: and address whether the Rooker-Feldman doctrine bars the plaintiffs from proceeding because they were in privity with a party in Salazar.  We conclude it does not
column3: and vacate the judgment of the District Court.

column1: II
This Court is vested
column3: with jurisdiction over appeals from final state-court judgments.  We have held that this grant of jurisdiction is exclusive: Review of such judgments may be had only in this Court.  District of Columbia Court of Appeals v. Feldman
column5: 482 (1983) (emphasis added); see also Atlantic Coast Line R. Co. v. Locomotive Engineers
column7: 286 (1970); Rooker v. Fidelity Trust Co.
column9: 416 (1923).  Accordingly
column10: under what has come to be known as the Rooker-Feldman doctrine
column11: lower federal courts are precluded from exercising appellate jurisdiction over final state-court judgments.

column1: The Rooker-Feldman doctrine takes its name from the only two cases in which we have applied this rule to find that a federal district court lacked jurisdiction.  In Rooker
column2: a party who had lost in the Indiana Supreme Court
column3: and failed to obtain review in this Court
column4: filed an action in federal district court challenging the constitutionality of the state-court judgment.  We viewed the action as tantamount to an appeal of the Indiana Supreme Court decision
column5: over which only this Court had jurisdiction
column6: and said that the aggrieved litigant cannot be permitted to do indirectly what he no longer can do directly.  263 U. S.
column7: at 416.  Feldman
column8: decided 60 years later
column9: concerned slightly different circumstances
column10: with similar results.  The plaintiffs there had been refused admission to the District of Columbia bar by the District of Columbia Court of Appeals
column11: and sought review of these decisions in federal district court.  Our decision held that to the extent plaintiffs challenged the Court of Appeals decisions themselvesas opposed to the bar admission rules promulgated nonjudicially by the Court of Appealstheir sole avenue of review was with this Court.  460 U. S.

column1: Neither Rooker nor Feldman elaborated a rationale for a wide-reaching bar on the jurisdiction of lower federal courts
column2: and our cases since Feldman have tended to emphasize the narrowness of the Rooker-Feldman rule.  See Exxon Mobil
column4: at 292 (Rooker-Feldman does not apply to parallel state and federal litigation); Verizon Md. Inc. v. Public Serv. Commn of Md.
column7: n. 3 (2002) (Rooker-Feldman has no application to judicial review of executive action
column8: including determinations made by a state administrative agency); Johnson v. De Grandy
column10: 10051006 (1994) (Rooker-Feldman does not bar actions by a nonparty to the earlier state suit).  Indeed
column12: this Court has never applied Rooker-Feldman to dismiss an action for want of jurisdiction.  Exxon Mobil

column1: In Exxon Mobil
column3: we warned that the lower courts have at times extended Rooker-Feldman far beyond the contours of the Rooker and Feldman cases
column4: overriding Congress conferral of federal-court jurisdiction concurrent with jurisdiction exercised by state courts
column5: and superseding the ordinary application of preclusion law pursuant to 28 U. S.C. 1738.  544 U. S.
column7: we explained
column8: is a narrow doctrine
column9: confined to cases brought by state-court losers complaining of injuries caused by state-court judgments rendered before the district court proceedings commenced and inviting district court review and rejection of those judgments.  544 U. S.

column1: Although we have never addressed the precise question before us
column2: we have held Rooker-Feldman inapplicable where the party against whom the doctrine is invoked was not a party to the underlying state-court proceeding.  See De Grandy
column3: supra
column5: the State of Florida sought
column7: to prevent the United States from bringing a challenge under 2 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 to the reapportionment of state electoral districts.  The Florida Supreme Court
column8: in an action initiated by the state attorney general
column9: had already declared the law valid under state and federal law.  We held that Rooker-Feldman did not bar the United States from bringing its own action in federal court because the United States was not a party in the state court
column10: and was in no position to ask this Court to review the state courts judgment and has not directly attacked it in this proceeding.  512 U. S.

column1: In the case before us
column2: plaintiffs were plainly not parties to the underlying state-court proceeding in Salazar.  Salazar was an action brought by the state attorney general against the secretary of state
column3: in which the Colorado General Assembly intervened.  79 P.3d
column4: at 1227.  The four citizen-plaintiffs here did not participate in Salazar
column5: and were not in a position to ask this Court to review the state courts judgment.  De Grandy
column7: at 1006; see Karcher v. May
column9: 77 (1987) ([T]he general rule [is] that one who is not a party or has not been treated as a party to a judgment has no right to appeal therefrom).

column1: Although the District Court recognized the general rule that Rooker-Feldman may not be invoked against a federal-court plaintiff who was not actually a party to the prior state-court judgment
column4: it nevertheless followed Tenth Circuit precedent in allowing application of Rooker-Feldman against parties who were in privity with a party to the earlier state-court action.  379 F.Supp. 2d
column5: at 1123 (citing Kenmen Eng. v. Union
column7: 481 (2002)).  In determining whether privity existed

column3: this Court would resist interpretation geared more to the protection of existing competitors than to the stimulation of competition.  There is no evidence here that any favored purchaser possesses market power
column4: the allegedly favored purchasers are dealers with little resemblance to large independent department stores or chain operations
column5: and the suppliers selective price discounting fosters competition among suppliers of different brands.  By declining to extend Robinson-Patmans governance to such cases
column6: the Court continues to construe the Act consistently with antitrust laws broader policies.  Pp.1314.
